Bill de hOra wrote (in
<http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/mes=
sage/11862>):

> Esme's API is as bad anything I saw in the SOAP/XMLRPC day=
s. I'm 
> dumbfounded this can get incubated in the ASF.

Bill was writing,=
 respectively, of the Enterprise Social Messaging
Experiment (<http://incub=
ator.apache.org/esme/>) and the Apache Software
Foundation (<http://www.apa=
che.org/foundation/>). I'll leave aside the
assessment of the ESME API (not=
 that I have arguments with Bill's
assessment, anyway). I want to address B=
ill's dumbfounding. I understand
his feeling, but don't share it. The time =
for surprise has passed; just
glance at the list of projects within the Apa=
che Software Foundation
(<http://projects.apache.org/indexes/alpha.html>) t=
o see what I mean.

I am a lurker
(<http://www.apache.org/foundation/how-it=
-works.html#users>) within the
Apache community, so I don't claim to know h=
ow the Apache Software
Foundation works. I have read "How the ASF works"
(<=
http://www.apache.org/foundation/how-it-works.html>), a publication of
the =
Apache Software Foundation. Consider the following passage from "How
the AS=
F works"
(<http://www.apache.org/foundation/how-it-works.html#incubator>):
=

> It must be noted that the incubator (just like the board) does not 
> pe=
rform filtering on the basis of technical issues. This is because 
> the fo=
undation respects and suggests variety of technical approaches. 
> It doesn=
't fear innovation or even internal confrontation between 
> projects which=
 overlap in functionality.

Do I need to comment further?

-- 
Please do no=
t copy me on public replies.
